title: 111_hr4390
content: The Act is titled the "Medicare and Medicaid Fraud Prevention and Control Act of 2009." It introduces enhanced program and provider protections in the Medicare, Medicaid, and CHIP programs. The Act "Medicare and Medicaid Fraud Prevention and Control Act of 2009" introduces enhanced program and provider protections in Medicare, Medicaid, and CHIP programs, including authorization for enhanced oversight periods and enrollment moratoria based on significant risk of fraudulent activity. The Act "Medicare and Medicaid Fraud Prevention and Control Act of 2009" allows the Secretary to impose requirements on providers or suppliers enrolling in Medicare, Medicaid, or CHIP programs, including screening and enhanced oversight periods. The Act allows the Secretary to impose requirements on providers enrolling in Medicare, Medicaid, or CHIP programs, including enhanced oversight periods, enrollment moratoria, and periodic validations of authorizations. States may be required to implement these provisions in their State plans. The Act allows the Secretary to impose requirements on providers enrolling in child health plan under title XXI. Actions taken and determinations made under this subsection shall not be subject to review by a judicial tribunal. Screening procedures are established for providers, including licensing board checks and screening against excluded individuals and entities. The Act allows the Secretary to impose requirements on providers enrolling in child health plans under title XXI, including screening procedures such as background checks and heightened disclosure of affiliations. An enhanced oversight period of 30 to 365 days is established for providers to ensure compliance. The Secretary can impose enhanced oversight on providers under titles XVIII, XIX, and XXI, including site visits, inspections, prepayment review, and extended oversight periods if necessary. The Secretary can impose enhanced oversight on suppliers of durable medical equipment if fraudulent activity is detected, withholding payment for specified periods. The Secretary can establish a program for periodic review of physician authorizations to address excessive prescribing or authorization of items or services. The program allows for review of physician authorizations to prevent excessive prescribing or authorization of items and services. If a physician fails to validate claims within 90 days, subsequent claims for prescribed items and services will be denied. The Secretary may impose a moratorium on enrollment of providers and suppliers in certain cases of ongoing fraud within Medicare, Medicaid, or CHIP programs to prevent adverse impacts. The Secretary can impose a moratorium on provider enrollment to prevent fraud, without limiting a State's ability to conduct provider oversight activities. Additionally, a probationary period is established for new providers to ensure legitimacy. During XVIII, XIX, or XXI, a probationary period of heightened review (up to 1 year) is imposed by the Secretary to validate provider operations and physician prescriptions for items and services. The Secretary may suspend or terminate a provider or supplier's participation if a significant number of claims are deemed illegitimate. This action is subject to the same provisions as exclusions under section 1128. The Secretary may impose a civil monetary penalty of up to $10,000 on a physician or professional who fails to cooperate in validating prescriptions. This penalty applies to items and services provided by a specific provider or supplier. The Prompt Pay Provisions in sections 1816(c)(2) may be revised. The Prompt Pay Provisions in sections 1816(c)(2) and 1842(c)(2) of the Social Security Act are being revised to exclude claims from providers or suppliers that show suspicious patterns of claim submission indicative of potential fraud. Additionally, there are conforming amendments for Medicaid in section 1902(a) of the Act. Medicaid provisions under the Social Security Act are being amended to include a moratorium on certain entities or individuals. The State will enforce determinations made by the Secretary regarding fraudulent activity by providers or suppliers. Medicaid provisions are being amended to include a moratorium on certain entities or individuals. The State child health plan must include procedures to enforce determinations made by the Secretary on fraudulent activity by providers or suppliers. The State child health plan must include procedures to enforce determinations made by the Secretary on fraudulent activity by providers or suppliers. Amendments to the Social Security Act require program integrity measures for Medicare enrollments and renewals. Consultation with the OIG is necessary for implementing these amendments. The Secretary of Health and Human Services consults with the Inspector General to identify providers or services at risk of fraud under Medicare, Medicaid, or the State children's health insurance program. Additional funding may be appropriated for this purpose. The amendments made by this section will take effect upon the enactment of the Act. Section 1128G(b) of the Social Security Act will apply to providers and suppliers approved for participation six months after the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will issue regulations within 6 months of the Act's enactment, which will be effective immediately on an interim basis. There will be a public comment period, and the Secretary may make changes based on feedback.
